items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message:
Tide locking where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea,  over the next two days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible today, Friday 7 November, and over the weekend. 
We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  The Broads and river levels will remain high over the next couple of days due to tide locking from the current spring tides.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10:00am tomorrow, Saturday 8 November 2025. or as the situation changes.

High tides and forecast weather conditions this morning may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 9am and 11am this morning, Friday 7 November. 
We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Lowestoft of 1.60 mAODN at 10:00am today, Friday 7 November, which is 0.14m above tide tables, Wind Force 4, South easterly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides and forecast weather conditions today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 11:30am and 1:30pm today, Friday 7 November. 
Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Harwich of 2.64 mAODN at 12:30pm today, Friday 7 November, which is 0.32m above tide tables, Wind Force 4, Southerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closing flood gates .It is possible that the flood alert will be issued again over the weekend. 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. 
Coastal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 11:30am and 1:30pm today, Friday 7 November. 
The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded.  Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Harwich of 2.64 mAODN at 12:30pm today, Friday 7 November, which is 0.32m above tide tables, Wind Force 4, Southerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closing flood gates .It is possible that the flood alert will be issued again over the weekend. 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
High tides today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 2:15 PM to 4:15 PM on 07/11/2025. 
The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.77mAOD at 3:15 PM on 07/11/2025.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. Flooding of properties is not expected.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is 10 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain steady for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 7:50PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Coastal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and work with emergency services and local authorities.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions this evening may lead to flooding.  

Flooding is possible over the high tides on Friday 7th November. 

Low lying coastal roads, promenades, car parks and harbours may be flooded. Areas at risk include Fowey, Lostwithiel, Polperro Harbour, Looe, Millendreath and the B3247 at Seaton. High tide at Plymouth on Friday is at 6:52pm. Forecast total high tide levels are 2.78mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.3m above tide table level. Force 4 Westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 1.6m are forecast over Friday pm tide.  Coastal conditions should ease by Saturday am tide.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 08 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions this evening may lead to flooding.  

Flooding is possible over the high tides on Friday 7th November. 

Low lying coastal roads, promenades, car parks, and harbours may be flooded. Areas particularly at risk include Swanpool, St Mawes, East Portholland, Mevagissey, and Par. High tide at Falmouth on Friday is 6:17pm. Forecast total high tide level is 2.60mAOD. Expect tide levels to be around 0.2m above tide table level. Force 4 Westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 1.6m are forecast over Friday pm tide. Coastal conditions should ease by Saturday am tide.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 08 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 7:15 PM to 9:15 PM this evening. 
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The forecast high water is at 8:15 PM on 07/11/2025 with a level of 7.51 mAODN with  Westerly force 4 winds (mAODN is height above average sea level). Please note all tide times are in local time and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.
The high tide levels are now falling and subsequent tides are below the alert threshold. 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers or on the coast. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and are closing flood gates. 
Avoid coastal roads and low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 08 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Tidal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: The weather forecast is turning more settled for a time. River levels are falling but larger water bodies such as Coniston will remain high into the weekend. We continue to monitor the situation. Do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 8th November 2025.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tide and forecast weather conditions on Friday 07 November may lead to flooding.

Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of the high tide this evening.

Areas particularly at risk include Lynmouth, Combe Martin, Hele, Ilfracombe, Lee, Instow, Appledore, Westward Ho!, and Clovelly, Bideford, Barnstaple. High tide at Ilfracombe is at 7:00PM on Friday, times of high water will vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide level is 5.10 mAOD which is around 0.29 metres above tide table level. Force 4 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 1.50m are forecast over the high tides. Coastal conditions should ease for Saturday morning's high tide.

We are closely monitoring the situation .

Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded .

This message will be updated by 12:30PM on 08 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are falling. Flooding is possible today, 07 November 2025. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 4.26m 05/11 AM, Maesbrook peaked at 1.42m on 05/11 PM, Cae Howel peaked at 4.13m 06/11 PM. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 7:00 PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Tidal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.  
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

This Flood Alert has been issued for midday tides on 07/11/2025. Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads on 07/11/2025 at the following locations: Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 12:45 PM. Eastford Road, peaking around 13:00 PM. Arpley Bridge, peaking around 13:15 PM.  It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. We are expecting water levels to fall after this time and will update as necessary. Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 07/11/2025, or as the situation changes.

High tides on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Friday morning's tide at 11:30 on 07/11/2025 and 13:42 on 07/11/2025. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. Total forecast tide is 4.08 metres Chart Datum (2.24 mAOD) at Beaulieu. Light Southerly Force 4 wind. The tide will flood into the garden of the mill house on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. Minor road flooding at Palace Lane is also expected, making access to the village temporarily more difficult. Friday's tide at 23:45 on 07/11/2025 is forecast to be 21 cm lower (2.03 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 11:00AM to 1:00PM on 7/11/2025. 
We are in a period of high tides and a Flood Alert is expected to remain in force for the following tides that also meet Flood Alert Level. Next high tide at alert level is 08/11/2025 12:30AM.  This will bring an end to the current high tide cycle.

Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued by the Environment Agency. 

Flood alert in force: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester.

Flooding is possible for: River Dee in England covers areas around Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. 

River levels are predicted to begin falling throughout the afternoon.

Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. Townfield Lane may be cut off. 

We are closely monitoring the situation . 

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 

This message will be updated by 17:00 PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.  
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.    
We will continue to monitor the situation and work with emergency services and local authorities.    
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

High river levels on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 07 November 2025 1.5 hours before, and 3.5 hours after the tide at 11:30. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. Total forecast tide is 5.17 metres Chart Datum (2.43 mAOD) at Southampton. Light Southerly Force 4 wind. Levels in the lower River Itchen will increase as the incoming tide prevents water from flowing out to sea. Footpath flooding will affect some areas of Riverside Park. The pub car park at Mansbridge, may see minor impact flooding for a short period of time. Any flood depth would be relatively shallow. The tide will not flood property or the A27. Friday's tide at 23:45 on 07/11/2025 is forecast to be 23 cm lower (2.2 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Friday morning's tide at 11:30 on 07/11/2025 and 13:42 on 07/11/2025. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. Total forecast tide is 5.17 metres Chart Datum (2.43 mAOD) at Southampton. Light Southerly Force 4 wind. Very minor impact flooding will affect the lower floor level of Eling Tide Mill and boat yards at Bursledon. Road and car park flooding may occur at The Quay Hamble, Magazine Lane at Marchwood and Shore Road in Hythe. Friday's tide at 23:45 on 07/11/2025 is forecast to be 23 cm lower (2.2 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Friday afternoon's tide at 12:00 on 07/11/2025. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. Total forecast tide is 5.33 metres Chart Datum (2.60 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Light Southerly Force 4 wind. Levels will be high at South Street and Queen Street Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park, Langstone will flood. Water will flow across the A259 junction with Lumley Road, flooding driveways. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street. Flood depths in the road will be up to 0.1m deep, and should only cause impacts nearest to the harbour front. Saturday's tide at 00:15 on 08/11/2025 is forecast to be 19 cm lower (2.41 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Friday morning's tide at 11:41 on 07/11/2025. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.12 m. Total forecast tide is 4.67 metres Chart Datum (2.08 mAOD) at Cowes. Light Southerly Force 4 wind. Very minor impact flooding will affect some sea front roads, esplanades and car parks across the island. Water will be high up slipways in Cowes, affecting Medina Road and the floating bridge. In East Cowes, sea water forced up through drains may cause very minor impacts to the road at Albany Road. Friday's tide at 23:56 on 07/11/2025 is forecast to be 23 cm lower (1.85 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 12pm and 2pm today, Friday 7 November. 
Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Clacton of 2.82 mAODN at 12:30pm today, Friday 7 November, which is 0.14m above tide tables, Wind Force 4, Southerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closing flood gates . It is possible that the flood alert will be issued again over the weekend 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation .

High tides this evening may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible from 8pm today 07/11/25 and tomorrow morning from 8am 08/11/25. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.4m to 7.7m this evening, 07/11/25, Newport 6.9m to 7.2m this evening, 07/11/25. Tomorrow morning's high tide is forecast between 8 and 9am, 08/11/25. Predicted peaks :- Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.6m, Newport 6.8m to 7.1m. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. items.message:
Higher than normal tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 09:30 to 13:30 on Friday 7 November 2025. 
Flooding will be localised and low lying land near the coast is expected to be most affected, particularly around Ramsgate, Sandwich and Deal. The detailed forecast is for a peak tide of 3.65m AoD at Dover at 11:30. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 12pm and 2pm today, Friday 7 November. 
Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Southend of 3.61 mAODN at 1pm today, Friday 7 November, which is 0.32m above tide tables, Wind Force 4, Southerly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: North Sea coast at Easington and Kilnsea
items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.  
Coastal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.    
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.    
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from the Thames Barrier to Putney Bridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: City of London, Greater London, Greenwich, Hammersmith and Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea, Lambeth, Lewisham, Newham, Southwark, Tower Hamlets, Wandsworth, Westminster

items.message:
High tides today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 1:15 PM to 3:15 PM on 07/11/2025. 
The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.45mAOD at 2:15 PM on 07/11/2025.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3). Flooding of properties is not expected.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is 10 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain steady for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 8:04PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides, strong winds and large waves this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 7:00 to 9:00 PM on 07/11/2025. 
The forecast high water is at 8:00 PM on 07/11/2025 and the forecast tide level is 6.47 mAOD. The forecast wind is up to Force 4, Westerly. 
The next high water is lower, at 6.24 mAOD, at 06.15 AM on 08/11/2025, however with similar wind direction and force. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will update the message as the situation changes. 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded and take care. 
This message will be updated by 12:00AM on 08 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Tidal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
High tides this afternoon may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 11:15 AM to 03:15 PM today on Friday 07/11/2025. 
Areas most at risk include low lying land, promenades and coastal footpaths. For those that need it, the forecast peak high water level is 3.56 m AOD at 01:15 PM.

High spring tides are expected to continue into the weekend so the risk of flooding may remain. We will update this Flood Alert message with subsequent high tides as necessary. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . Please take care because large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: The Solent, Portsmouth Harbour, Langstone Harbour

items.message:
High tides on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Friday afternoon's tide at 12:00 on 07/11/2025. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. Total forecast tide is 5.33 metres Chart Datum (2.60 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Light Southerly Force 4 wind. In Old Portsmouth, the tide may just exceed the top of the main slipway which will cause minor road flooding in East Street and to the boat yards at The Camber. To protect property in Old Portsmouth, tidal defence gates will be closed. Saturday's tide at 00:15 on 08/11/2025 is forecast to be 19 cm lower (2.41 mAOD). 
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

High tides on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 1 hour either side of Friday afternoon's tide at 12:00 on 07/11/2025. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. Total forecast tide is 5.33 metres Chart Datum (2.60 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Light Southerly Force 4 wind. Water may just exceed the top of the main slipway, flooding the road at Lower Quay, Fareham. The lower end of Wallington Shore Road will flood to a depth of 0.1m. Saturday's tide at 00:15 on 08/11/2025 is forecast to be 19 cm lower (2.41 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Coastal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and work with emergency services and local authorities.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.message: The weather forecast is turning more settled for a time. River levels are falling but larger water bodies such as Windermere will remain high into the weekend. We continue to monitor the situation. Do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 8th November 2025.

items.description: The Essex coast from Fobbing to Purfleet-on-Thames
items.message:
High tides and forecast weather conditions today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 12pm and 2pm today, Friday 7 November. 
Areas most at risk are within low lying land around Corringham, Tilbury, Grays, Thurrock and Purfleet-on-Thames. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Southend of 3.61 mAODN at 1:00pm today, Friday 7 November, which is 0.32m above tide tables, Wind Force 4, South easterly. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. 
We are closing flood gates It is possible that the flood alert will be issued again over the weekend. 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 November 2025 or as the situation changes.
